questions.question: What is the specific purpose of the `<meta charset='UTF-8'>` tag, and why is it critical for modern web applications?

answer_variants.answer: It informs the browser to use UTF-8 character encoding, preventing 'mojibake' (garbled text) when rendering diverse characters/emojis.

It declares the character encoding of the document as UTF-8. Without it, browsers may guess the encoding (heuristics), potentially choosing an incorrect legacy encoding (like Windows-1252), causing security vulnerabilities (XSS) or display errors.

It tells the browser which alphabet to use. UTF-8 includes almost every character in the world (English, Japanese, Emojis). Without it, some characters might look like weird diamonds with question marks.

It ensures the browser correctly interprets the bytes of the file. UTF-8 is the universal standard. Missing it can lead to character corruption and, in rare cases, security bypasses where filters fail to catch malicious scripts encoded in different formats.

The UTF-8 declaration must occur within the first 1024 bytes of the HTML to be effective. It prevents 'Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via Encoding' attacks, where an attacker tricks the browser into interpreting non-standard encodings to bypass sanitizer limits.
It's like agreeing on a codebook. If I send you Morse code but you try to read it as Braille, it makes no sense. `charset='UTF-8'` ensures we are both using the Universal Codebook.
1. Browser reads bytes. 2. Needs explicit encoding map. 3. `UTF-8` covers all languages. 4. Without it -> Guesswork -> Display errors.

This tag specifies the character encoding. It is critical for two reasons: 1) Internationalization support (rendering non-ASCII characters), and 2) Security (preventing encoding-based XSS attacks). It should always be the first tag in the head.
It makes sure emojis and foreign letters show up correctly. If you don't put it, you get those ugly question mark symbols.

The tag sets the document's character set to UTF-8. This is the dominant standard on the web, supporting variable-width character encoding for all Unicode characters. Omitting it forces the browser to rely on user-locale defaults or unreliable sniffing, creating significant robustness and security risks.

questions.question: Explain the role of the `<title>` tag. Where is it displayed, and how does it impact SEO?

answer_variants.answer: The title appears in the browser tab and search engine results; it is the single most important on-page SEO factor.
The `<title>` element defines the document's title that is shown in a browser's title bar or a page's tab. It is metadata, not part of the document body.
It's the text you see on the browser tab at the very top. It's also the big blue link you click on Google. It tells people what your page is about.

The title tag is crucial for UX (browser tabs, bookmarks) and SEO. Google uses it as the primary headline in SERPs (Search Engine Results Pages). It should be unique, descriptive, and contain main keywords.

The `<title>` is a required element in HTML documents. Search engines weigh words in the title heavily for ranking. Ideally, it follows the format 'Primary Keyword - Secondary Keyword | Brand Name' and stays under 60 characters to avoid truncation in SERPs.
The `<title>` is like the title on a book's spine. It's how you find the book on a shelf (Google) and what you see when it's stacked (Browser Tabs).
1. Code: `<title>My Page</title>`. 2. Browser: Shows in Tab. 3. Google: Shows as Blue Link. 4. User: Decides to click.

The title tag appears in browser tabs and as the main clickable link in search results. It is the highest-weight on-page SEO element. We fix it by ensuring it is unique, keyword-relevant, and concise (<60 chars).
It's the name of the tab. It's important because that's what shows up on Google.

The `<title>` element provides the main label for the document. It serves three key roles: 1) Browser chrome label (tabs/bookmarks), 2) Accessibility name (screen readers announce it on load), and 3) Search Engine headline. It is a mandatory element in the head section.

questions.question: What does `<meta name='viewport' content='width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0'>` do?

answer_variants.answer: It instructs the browser to set the viewport width equal to the device screen width, enabling responsive design on mobile.
This meta tag controls the viewport's size and scaling. `width=device-width` sets the width of the page to follow the screen-width of the device. `initial-scale=1.0` sets the initial zoom level.
Without this line, phones pretend to be desktop computers and shrink your whole website to be tiny. This line tells the phone 'I am mobile-friendly, please show me at normal size'.

It resets the mobile browser's default behavior. By default, mobile browsers render at ~980px wide and zoom out. This tag forces the rendering viewport to match the physical device pixels (DIPs), allowing CSS media queries to trigger correctly.

It harmonizes the layout viewport with the visual viewport. `width=device-width` ensures `100vw` equals the logical screen width. `initial-scale=1.0` prevents default zooming. It is the trigger for Responsive Web Design (RWD).
It's like telling a printer to print on 'Letter Size' instead of shrinking a 'Poster Size' image onto a small paper. It matches content to canvas.
1. Default mobile: Zoomed out, tiny text. 2. Add viewport tag. 3. Browser: 'Okay, I will match width to screen.' 4. Result: Readable text, responsive layout.

This is the viewport meta tag, essential for Responsive Design. It prevents mobile browsers from rendering the page as a zoomed-out desktop site. It aligns the viewport width with the device independent pixels.
It makes the website look good on phones. If you forget it, the site looks tiny on mobile.

The `viewport` meta tag overrides the browser's default 'virtual viewport' (usually 980px). By setting `width=device-width`, it instructs the browser to calculate layout based on the device's actual DIP width, allowing media queries to function as intended.

questions.question: Compare `<script>`, `<script async>`, and `<script defer>`. Which one blocks the HTML parser?

answer_variants.answer: Standard `<script>` blocks parsing; `async` downloads in parallel but executes immediately (blocking parsing then); `defer` downloads in parallel and executes *after* HTML parsing.

`<script>`: Fetches and executes immediately, pausing HTML parsing. `async`: Fetches in background, pauses HTML only to execute when ready. `defer`: Fetches in background, executes only after DOMContentLoaded.
Normal script stops everything to load. `Async` loads in the background but runs whenever it wants (random order). `Defer` loads in the background and runs politely at the end (correct order).

Use `defer` for dependent scripts (jQuery plugins) as order is preserved. Use `async` for independent scripts (Analytics) where order doesn't matter. Standard script is bad for performance if in `<head>`.

Parser Blocking behavior: `<script>` blocks the main thread during Fetch and Execution. `async` eliminates Fetch blocking but blocks during Execution (which is indeterminate). `defer` eliminates all blocking usage during parsing, running strictly before `DOMContentLoaded`. `defer` is the most performant for application bundles.

Script = Stop reading, go buy milk, drink it, continue. Async = Ask mom to buy milk, keep reading, stop reading when she returns to drink it. Defer = Ask mom to buy milk, keep reading, drink it only when finished reading.
1. `<script>`: Pause Parser -> Download -> Run -> Resume. 2. `async`: Download Parallel -> Pause Parser -> Run -> Resume. 3. `defer`: Download Parallel -> Finish Parsing -> Run.

Normal scripts block formatting manifest. `async` is non-blocking download but blocks execution interrupts parsing. `defer` is non-blocking download and deferred execution. I use `defer` for my main bundle to ensure the DOM is ready and execution order is preserved.
Normal script stops the page loading. Async and Defer make it faster. Defer waits until the end to run, which is usually safer.

Standard scripts are synchronous parser-blocking resources. `async` attributes decouple downloading from parsing, but execution interrupts the parser the moment the resource is available (race conditions possible). `defer` decouples both, scheduling execution for the `DOMContentLoaded` event, ensuring the Document Object Model is fully constructed before logic runs.

questions.question: What is the 'DOM' vs the 'Render Tree'? Which tags are in the DOM but NOT in the Render Tree?

answer_variants.answer: DOM is the full content tree; Render Tree is the visual tree (DOM + CSSOM). `<head>`, `<meta>`, and `display: none` elements are in the DOM but missing from the Render Tree.

The DOM (Document Object Model) represents the full HTML structure. The Render Tree represents the visual rectangles to be painted. Non-visual elements like `<head>`, `<script>`, or elements with `display: none` exist in the DOM but are excluded from the Render Tree.
The DOM is everything in your code. The Render Tree is only what the user can see. Things like hidden text or 'metadata' are in the DOM but not the Render Tree.

The browser constructs the DOM from HTML. Then it combines it with CSS to make the Render Tree. Elements with `display: none` are completely removed from the Render Tree (no geometry), whereas `visibility: hidden` elements stay in the Render Tree (transparent box).

Render Tree construction (attachment) involves calculating visual properties. The Render Tree contains 'RenderObjects'. It excludes non-rendered DOM nodes (Head, Meta) and CSS-hidden nodes (`display: none`). Note valid distinction: `display: none` removes from Render Tree; `visibility: hidden` keeps it (for layout spacing).
DOM is the script of a play (contains stage directions, lighting notes). Render Tree is the actual actors on stage. The 'lighting notes' (Metadata) are in the script but not on stage.
1. HTML -> DOM. 2. CSS -> CSSOM. 3. DOM + CSSOM -> Render Tree. 4. Filter: Remove `display: none` and `<head>`. 5. Result: Render Tree used for Layout.

The DOM represents the document content. The Render Tree represents the visual layout. Tags like `<head>`, `<meta>`, and elements styled with `display: none` are present in the DOM but absent from the Render Tree because they have no visual geometry.
DOM is the code. Render Tree is the picture. Stuff like the title tag is in the code but you don't see it on the page body, so it's not in the Render Tree.

The DOM is a node tree reflecting the HTML document. The Render Tree is a hierarchy of visual objects text/boxes calculated from the DOM and CSSOM. Elements that do not occupy space (like `<meta>` tags or `display: none` elements) are pruned during Render Tree construction to optimize the Layout and Paint phases.

questions.question: Why is the `alt` attribute on `` tags mandatory for valid HTML and accessibility?

answer_variants.answer: It provides text fallback if the image fails to load and is read by screen readers for blind users.
The `alt` attribute specifies alternate text for an area, used by screen readers (Accessibility) and displayed if the image resource fails to load (Availability).
If the picture breaks, the `alt` text shows up so people know what was there. Also, blind people use special software that reads this text to describe the picture to them.

It acts as a substitute for the image. SEO crawlers read it to understand image content. Screen readers announce it. If purely decorative, use `alt=''` (empty string) to tell screen readers to skip it, but do not omit the attribute completely.

WCAG guidelines require non-text content to have a text alternative. Omitting `alt` makes the screen reader read the filename (e.g., 'image_005.jpg'), which is poor UX. An empty `alt=''` allows the image to be treated as a presentation artifact and ignored.
It's like a caption describing a photo for someone listening to the radio. Without the caption, they just hear 'Photo', which is useless.
1. Screen reader hits ``. 2. Checks `alt`. 3. If text: Reads text. 4. If empty: Skips. 5. If missing: Reads filename (bad).

The `alt` attribute is critical for Accessibility (Screen Readers) and SEO. Text content allows search engines to index images. For decorative images, we explicitly use an empty string `alt=''` to prevent screen reader clutter.
It describes the image. It's for blind people and also helps Google know what the image is.

The `alt` attribute is the textual equivalent of the image data. Its presence is required for HTML validity. It serves three roles: Accessibility (Screen reader description), Reliability (Fallback text on 404), and SEO (Image indexing context). Omission results in significant barriers for visually impaired users.

questions.question: What is the difference between `<strong>`/`<em>` and `<b>`/`<i>`? Why prefer the former?

answer_variants.answer: `<strong>`/`<em>` describe meaning (Importance/Emphasis), while `<b>`/`<i>` describe appearance (Bold/Italic). Always prefer semantic meaning.

`<strong>`: Strong importance. `<em>`: Emphatic stress. `<b>`: Stylic distinction (bold) without importance. `<i>`: Alternate voice (italic) without emphasis. Semantic tags translate to accessibility API properties; style tags do not.
`<b>` just makes text bold. `<strong>` makes it bold BUT also tells the computer 'This is super important!'. Blind users hear a difference in voice tone with `<strong>`, but not with `<b>`.

Use `<strong>` for warnings or key phrases (semantics). Use `<b>` for keywords or product names where you want bolding but no extra importance. Screen readers may add vocal stress to `<strong>`/`<em>`.

This is Separation of Concerns. `<b>` and `<i>` are presentational tags (older HTML). `<strong>` and `<em>` are semantic. While browsers default style them identically, you should use semantics. To just make text bold visually, use CSS `font-weight`. Use tags only if the meaning matches.
`<b>` is like yelling. `<strong>` is like saying 'Listen, this is crucial'. Yelling is just noise; importance has meaning.
1. Need bold text? 2. Is it important? Yes -> `<strong>`. 3. just decoration? -> CSS or `<b>`. 4. Semantics wins.

`<strong>` and `<em>` carry semantic weight (strong importance/emphasis), impacting Accessibility tools. `<b>` and `<i>` are purely presentational. We prefer semantic tags to decouple structure from style, or use CSS for purely visual bolding.
They look the same, but `strong` means it's important. `b` just means bold. Use `strong` for better coding style.

The distinction is between Semantics and Presentation. `<strong>` indicates text of strong importance, and `<em>` indicates stress emphasis, which screen readers may interpret via intonation. `<b>` and `<i>` are stylistic containers with no semantic value (used for taxonomy terms, foreign phrases). In modern HTML5, strictly using semantic tags or CSS is preferred over presentational markup.

questions.question: What is the 'Favicon' and how do you implement it correctly for modern devices?

answer_variants.answer: It is the small icon in the browser tab; implemented via `<link rel='icon' href='favicon.ico'>`.
Favicon (Favorite Icon) serves as the visual identifier for the site in tabs and bookmarks. Implementation requires a valid `.ico`, `.png`, or `.svg` linked via `<link rel='icon'>` in the head.
It's the tiny logo you see next to the website name in the tab. You add it with a special link tag in the HTML head.
Modern implementation requires multiple sizes. Standard `favicon.ico` (32x32) for legacy. `icon.png` (192x192) for high-res screens. `apple-touch-icon` for iOS home screen shortcuts.

Best practice is to use SVG for the favicon (resolution independent) with a PNG fallback. You should also include a `webmanifest` file linked via `<link rel='manifest'>` to define icons for PWA (Progressive Web App) installation scenarios on Android/Desktop.
It's the flag flying on top of your castle. Without it, your castle just looks like a generic building (default page icon).
1. Create `.ico` file. 2. Create PNGs (192, 512). 3. Add `<link rel='icon' href='path'>`. 4. Add `apple-touch-icon`.

A Favicon is the site identifier. We implement it using `<link rel='icon'>`. For robust support, we include a `favicon.ico` for legacy browsers, a `image/png` for modern tabs, and an `apple-touch-icon` for iOS devices.
It's the tab icon. You put a link tag in the head pointing to the image file.

The Favicon is a resource linked via the `<link>` element associated with the `icon` relationship. While historically a `32x32` ICO file, modern standards support SVG and PNG. It is vital for UX as it provides visual recognition in the browser UI, bookmarks, and mobile home screen shortcuts.

questions.question: What is 'Open Graph' (OG) and why would you add it to your HTML?

answer_variants.answer: Open Graph protocol tags (`og:title`, `og:image`) control how your page looks when shared on social media (Facebook, LinkedIn, Discord).
Open Graph is a metadata protocol allowing web pages to become rich objects in a social graph. It defines tags like `og:title`, `og:type`, `og:image`, and `og:url`.
When you paste a link into WhatsApp or Facebook, and it pops up with a nice picture and title? That is Open Graph working. If you don't add it, the link looks boring.
It provides structured data to social crawlers. Standard meta tags are for Google; `og:` tags are for Facebook/LinkedIn/Slack. Essential for click-through rates (CTR) on social shares.

Developed by Facebook, OG tags transform a URL into a rich object. `og:image` is arguably the most critical for engagement. Twitter (X) has its own `twitter:card` tags but falls back to Open Graph if Twitter tags are missing.
It's the 'Business Card' your website hands out when it meets Social Media. Without it, Social Media just writes your name on a napkin.
1. Add `<meta property='og:title'>`. 2. Add `<meta property='og:image'>`. 3. Share link. 4. Platform renders rich card.

Open Graph tags allow us to control the preview snippet (Title, Description, Image) displayed on social networks. Implementing them increases brand visibility and click-through rates when content is shared.
It controls the preview card on Facebook. You know, the image and title that pop up when you share a link.

The Open Graph protocol standardizes metadata usage for social graph integration. By defining `og:title`, `og:description`, and `og:image`, developers dictate exactly how the URL is represented in the social feed, preventing the scraper from arbitrarily picking a random image or truncated text.

questions.question: When should you use the `<table>` element, and when is it strictly forbidden?

answer_variants.answer: Use `<table>` for tabular data (e.g., financial reports); strictly forbidden for page layout (e.g., positioning headers/sidebars).
The `<table>` element represents data with more than one dimension (rows/columns). It is forbidden to use tables for presentation/layout purposes as this breaks accessibility and responsive design.
Use tables for spreadsheet stuffâ€”like a scoreboard or a price list. Do NOT use tables to arrange your pictures and text on the screen; use CSS Grid for that.

Tables are for data grids. Using them for layout is an obsolete practice (from the 1990s) that causes screen reader confusion (reading data cells instead of content flow) and makes mobile responsiveness extremely difficult.

Tables have a rigid layout algorithm. They are permitted for logical data sets. They are forbidden for layout because: 1) Accessibility (Screen readers enter 'Table Mode'), 2) Performance (Tables require more reflow calculations), 3) Responsiveness (Tables don't wrap natively). Use CSS Grid/Flexbox for layout.
A Table is a filing cabinet (for data). A Layout is a floor plan. Don't use filing cabinets to build the walls of your house.
1. Is it a chart/data? Yes -> `<table>`. 2. Is it just positioning text? Yes -> CSS Grid. 3. Never use tables for layout.

We strictly use `<table>` only for tabular data where column/row relationships matter. We forbid using tables for layout because it harms accessibility (linearization issues) and creates rigid structures that fail on mobile devices.
Use it for data like Excel stuff. Don't use it to design the page layout, that's old school and bad.

The `<table>` element is semantically reserved for multidimensional data. Misusing it for layout purposes is an anti-pattern known as 'Table-based Layout'. This creates accessibility barriers (non-linear navigation for blind users) and maintenance nightmares compared to modern CSS Layout capabilities (Flexbox/Grid).
